sen.j: 宣命（せんみょう）とは、天皇の命令を漢字だけの日本語体で記した文書であり、漢文体の詔勅に対していう。
sen.e: Senmyo (an imperial edict) is a written document in which emperor's commands are recorded in a Japanese orthography only with Chinese characters, as compared with Shochoku (an imperial edict) written in classical Chinese.

Senmyo is a written document in which emperor's commands are recorded in a Japanese orthography only with Chinese characters, as compared with Shochoku (an imperial edict) written in classical Chinese.
sen.cmt: 半角クォーテーションに変え前出補足を削除しました。
sen.e: Senmyo is a written document in which emperor's commands are recorded in a Japanese orthography only with Chinese characters, as compared with Shochoku (an imperial edict) written in classical Chinese.

sen.j: この文体を宣命体（-たい）、その表記法を宣命書（-がき）、また宣命を読み上げる使者を宣命使（-し）、宣命を記す紙を宣命紙（-し）という。
sen.e: This literary style is called Senmyo-tai (a grand style written in an imperial-edict manner) Senmyotai (Senmyo-style writing), its orthography Senmyo-tai Senmyogaki (the way of writing Senmyotai), a messenger who reads Senmyo Senmyoshi (a messenger for Senmyo), and the paper on which Senmyo is drawn Senmyoshi (paper for Senmyo).
sen.cmt: 「宣命体・宣命書（-たい）」の「宣命書（-たい）」がどういうものかよくわかりません。一応「宣命体の書き方で書くこと」としました。
sen.e: This literary style is called Senmyotai (a grand style written in an imperial-edict manner), its notation Senmyogaki, a messenger who reads Senmyo Senmyoshi (宣命使), and the paper on which Senmyo is drawn Senmyo-shi (宣命紙).
sen.cmt: 原文には 「宣命体・宣命書（-たい）、その表記法を宣命体・宣命書（-がき）」とありましたが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「宣命体（-たい）、その表記法を宣命書（-がき）」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出し、原文修正しました。
sen.e: This literary style is called Senmyotai (a grand style written in an imperial-edict manner), its notation Senmyogaki, a messenger who reads Senmyo Senmyoshi (宣命使), and the paper on which Senmyo is drawn Senmyo-shi (宣命紙).

sen.j: 宣命体は、漢字仮名交じり文の源泉となった文体で、かなの発達史上、大変重要な文書である。
sen.e: Senmyotai is a literary style which became the origin of a composition written in kanji and kana, so it is a very important document for the history of development of kana.
Senmyotai is a literary style which became the origin of a composition written in kanji and kana (the Japanese syllabary), so it is a very important document for the history of development of kana.
Senmyotai is a literary style which became the origin of a composition written in kanji and kana (the Japanese syllabary), so it is a very important document for the history of development of kana.

sen.j: 天皇が宣（の）りたまう大命（おおみこと、命令）の意で、本来は口頭で宣布され、それを宣命体で書記した。
sen.e: It means imperial commands (orders) emperors issued, so originally they were proclaimed verbally and recorded in Senmyotai.
It means imperial commands (orders) emperors issued, so originally they were proclaimed verbally and recorded in Senmyotai.
It means imperial commands (orders) emperors issued, so originally they were proclaimed verbally and recorded in Senmyotai.

sen.j: 奈良時代は朝賀・即位・改元・立后・立太子などの儀式に用いられ、平安時代以降は任大臣・贈位・神社・天皇陵などの告文にだけ用いられた。
sen.e: In the Nara period they were used at the ceremonies such as Choga (New Year greetings or well-wishes offered by retainers to the Emperor), enthronement, changing the name of an era, investiture of the Empress, investiture of the Crown Prince, and after the Heian period, only used for imperial instructions such as appointment of ministers, conferral of posthumous ranks, shrines and the Imperial mausoleum, and so.

In the Nara period they were used at the ceremonies such as Choga (New Year greetings or well-wishes offered by retainers to the Emperor), enthronement, changing the name of an era, investiture of the Empress, investiture of the Crown Prince, and after the Heian period, only used for imperial instructions such as appointment of ministers, conferral of posthumous ranks, shrines and the Imperial mausoleum, and so on.

In the Nara period they were used at the ceremonies such as Choga (New Year greetings or well-wishes offered by retainers to the Emperor), enthronement, changing the name of an era, investiture of the Empress, investiture of the Crown Prince, and after the Heian period, only used for imperial instructions such as appointment of ministers, conferral of posthumous ranks, shrines and the Imperial mausoleum, and so on.

sen.j: 宣命・祝詞などの文体を宣命体といい、その表記法である宣命書とは、品詞・品詞の語幹を大きな字で書き、助詞・助動詞 (国文法)・用言の語尾などは、一字一音の万葉仮名で小さく右に寄せて書く方法である。
sen.e: The literary style such as Senmyo and Norito (Shinto prayers) is referred to as Senmyotai, and its orthography, Senmyogaki, is a way of writing in which parts of speech and stems of words are written in large characters, and postpositional particles, auxiliary verbs (Japanese grammar), ending of declinable words, and so on, in flush-right smaller characters of word-and-sound Manyogana (a form of syllabary used in the Manyo-shu or Collection of Myriad Leaves).

The literary style such as Senmyo and Norito (Shinto prayers) is referred to as Senmyotai, and its orthography, Senmyogaki, is a way of writing in which parts of speech and stems of words are written in large characters, and postpositional particles, auxiliary verbs (Japanese grammar), ending of declinable words, and so on, in flush-right smaller characters of word-and-sound Manyogana (a form of syllabary used in the Manyoshu [Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves]).
sen.cmt: 半角英字にし、用語集に合わせました。
sen.e: The literary style such as Senmyo and Norito (Shinto prayers) is referred to as Senmyotai, and its orthography, Senmyogaki, is a way of writing in which parts of speech and stems of words are written in large characters, and postpositional particles, auxiliary verbs (Japanese grammar), ending of declinable words, and so on, in flush-right smaller characters of word-and-sound Manyogana (a form of syllabary used in the Manyoshu [Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves]).

sen.j: 「を」には「乎」、「の」には「乃」、「は」には「波」などを一定して使っている。
sen.e: 乎' is regularly used for 'wo' (を), '乃' for 'no' (の), '波' for 'ha' (は), and so on.
乎' is regularly used for 'wo' (を), '乃' for 'no' (の), '波' for 'ha' (は), and so on.
乎' is regularly used for 'wo' (を), '乃' for 'no' (の), '波' for 'ha' (は), and so on.

sen.j: ただし、宣命体には2種類ある。
sen.e: However, there are two kinds of Senmyotai.
However, there are two kinds of Senmyotai.
However, there are two kinds of Senmyotai.

sen.j: 助詞なども含めてすべて大字で書かれる宣命大書体と、上述のように助詞などを小字で書き分ける宣命小書体である。
sen.e: Senmyodaishotai in which all words including postpositional particles, and so on, are written in large characters, and Senmyoshoshotai in which postpositional particles, and so on, are differently written in smaller characters as described above.
sen.cmt: 「すべて大字で書かれる」のところに、「すべての語が大字で書かれる」の意味でall wordsを付け加えました。
sen.e: Senmyo Daishotai in which all words including postpositional particles, and so on, are written in large characters, and Senmyo Shoshotai in which postpositional particles, and so on, are differently written in smaller characters as described above.
sen.cmt: 半角英字にし、用語集に合わせました。
sen.e: Senmyo Daishotai in which all words including postpositional particles, and so on, are written in large characters, and Senmyo Shoshotai in which postpositional particles, and so on, are differently written in smaller characters as described above.

sen.j: 宣命書は、「漢字万葉仮名交じり文」と言えるが、その万葉仮名を平仮名に変えると、「漢字仮名交じり文」とほぼ同じになり、これは日本語表記の展開史の上で注目すべき出来事であった。
sen.e: Senmyogaki can be called 'a composition written in kanji and manyogana', but if the manyogana is changed to hiragana, it becomes almost the same as 'a composition written in kanji and kana', which is a remarkable thing in the history of development of the Japanese orthography.

Senmyogaki can be called 'a composition written in kanji and manyogana,' but if the manyogana is changed to hiragana, it becomes almost the same as 'a composition written in kanji and kana,' which is a remarkable thing in the history of development of the Japanese orthography.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションの位置を変えました。
sen.e: Senmyogaki can be called 'a composition written in kanji and manyogana,' but if the manyogana is changed to hiragana, it becomes almost the same as 'a composition written in kanji and kana,' which is a remarkable thing in the history of development of the Japanese orthography.

sen.j: 古代朝鮮の吏読が宣命体を導いたと推測されている。
sen.e: It has been presumed that Rito of ancient Korea led to Senmyotai.
It has been presumed that Rito (an expression of Korean in Chinese characters) of ancient Korea led to Senmyotai.
It has been presumed that Rito (an expression of Korean in Chinese characters) of ancient Korea led to Senmyotai.

sen.j: 朝鮮語は日本語とよく似た言語で、助詞や助動詞などの文法的要素を必要とするため、漢文で書かれていた古代朝鮮の公文書にこれらの朝鮮語を書き加えることがおこってくる。
sen.e: Korean is a similar language to Japanese and it needs grammatical elements such as postpositional particles and auxiliary verbs, and so on, therefore, it sometimes happens to insert these Korean words to ancient Korean official documents written in Chinese classics.

Korean is a similar language to Japanese and it needs grammatical elements such as postpositional particles and auxiliary verbs, and so on, therefore, it sometimes happens to insert these Korean words to ancient Korean official documents written in Chinese classics.

Korean is a similar language to Japanese and it needs grammatical elements such as postpositional particles and auxiliary verbs, and so on, therefore, it sometimes happens to insert these Korean words to ancient Korean official documents written in Chinese classics.

sen.j: これを吏読というが、原則として漢文の各分節の終わりにその要素を送りがなのように漢字で記した。
sen.e: This is called Rito, where in principle at the end of each segment of Chinese classics its elements were described in Chinese charcters like okurigana (kana added to a Chinese character to show its pronunciation).
sen.cmt: 用語集では「かな」の英訳がありましたが、長いので「送りがな」をローマ字にし、用語集の説明を括弧に入れました。
sen.e: This is called Rito, where in principle at the end of each segment of Chinese classics its elements were described in Chinese characters like okurigana (kana added to a Chinese character to show its pronunciation).

This is called Rito, where in principle at the end of each segment of Chinese classics its elements were described in Chinese characters like okurigana (kana added to a Chinese character to show its pronunciation).

sen.j: この方法は日本の宣命書と同じであり、ここに吏読が宣命体のモデルという推測が生まれた。
sen.e: This method is the same as Japanese Senmyogaki, which caused a speculation that Rito was a model of Senmyotai.
This method is the same as Japanese Senmyogaki, which caused a speculation that Rito was a model of Senmyotai.
This method is the same as Japanese Senmyogaki, which caused a speculation that Rito was a model of Senmyotai.

sen.j: ただ、仮名を小さく書く宣命小書体に進展したのは、我が国における成果である。
sen.e: However, the development into Senmyoshoshotai where kana is written in a small size is an achievement in our country.
However, the development into Senmyo Shoshotai where kana is written in a small size is an achievement in our country.
However, the development into Senmyo Shoshotai where kana is written in a small size is an achievement in our country.

sen.j: 宣命を記す紙で、普通は黄麻紙（おうまし）を用い、伊勢神宮には縹色の紙、賀茂神社には紅色の紙を用いた。
sen.e: Paper to describe Senmyo - usually omashi (yellowish paper made of hemp) was used; hanadairo-colored (light blue) paper for Ise-jingu Shrine, and crimson paper for Kamo-jinja Shrine.
Paper to describe Senmyo, for which omashi (yellowish paper made of hemp) was usually used, and hanadairo-colored (light blue) paper for Ise-jingu Shrine, and crimson paper for Kamo-jinja Shrine.
Paper to describe Senmyo, for which omashi (yellowish paper made of hemp) was usually used, and hanadairo-colored (light blue) paper for Ise-jingu Shrine, and crimson paper for Kamo-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 黄麻紙とは、アサを主体に造った紙で、害虫を防ぐために黄檗で染めたため、その色からこの名がある。
sen.e: Omashi refers to the paper mainly made of hemp and dyed with kihada (Amur cork) to prevent insect pests, which leads to the name of the paper.
Omashi refers to the paper mainly made of hemp and dyed with kihada (Amur cork) to prevent insect pests, which leads to the name of the paper.
Omashi refers to the paper mainly made of hemp and dyed with kihada (Amur cork) to prevent insect pests, which leads to the name of the paper.

sen.j: 古来より麻は清浄なものとされていたので、奈良時代の写経にも多く使用された。
sen.e: As hemp had been believed to be clean since ancient times, it was often used for copying sutras in the Nara period.
As hemp had been believed to be clean since ancient times, it was often used for copying sutras in the Nara period.
As hemp had been believed to be clean since ancient times, it was often used for copying sutras in the Nara period.

sen.j: 『続日本紀』には、697年、文武天皇の即位時のものをはじめとする宣命が62編、収録されている。
sen.e: In "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) 62 pieces of Senmyo including the time of enthronement of Emperor Monmu in 697 are recorded.
In "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) 62 pieces of Senmyo including the time of enthronement of Emperor Monmu in 697 are recorded.
In "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) 62 pieces of Senmyo including the time of enthronement of Emperor Monmu in 697 are recorded.

sen.j: しかし、いずれも原本は現存しない。
sen.e: However, none of the original scripts exist.
However, none of the original scripts exist.
However, none of the original scripts exist.

tit.cmt: 「孝謙天皇」は女性天皇ですのでEmpress Kokenとしました。http://kotobank.jp/word/%E5%AD%9D%E8%AC%99%E5%A4%A9%E7%9A%87

sen.j: 天平勝宝9年（757年）3月25日の孝謙天皇宣命の転写が正倉院文書・正集第44巻に収めされている。
sen.e: A copy of Empress Koken's Senmyo of April 22, 757, is included in Shoso-in Monjo (documents of Shoso-in Treasure Repository) Shoshu vol. 44.
A copy of Empress Koken's Senmyo of April 22, 757, is included in Shoso-in Monjo (documents of Shoso-in Treasure Repository) Shoshu volume 44.
sen.cmt: 半角クォーテーションにしました。
sen.e: A copy of Empress Koken's Senmyo of April 22, 757, is included in Shoso-in Monjo (documents of Shoso-in Treasure Repository) Shoshu volume 44.

sen.j: 天皇 我 大命 良末等 宣 布 大命 乎
sen.e: 天皇 我 大命 良末等 宣 布 大命 乎
sen.cmt: ここから5段は宣命の例です。この日本語がもう一度後列に出てきますのでそれを英訳し、この欄は一応そのまま漢字を書きました。和訳は早川庄八（1993）『続日本紀』岩波書店pp. 51-52によるものです。参考までに日本語訳を書いておきます。この欄の訳は、「天皇が大命として宣布される大命を、」
sen.e: 天皇 我 大命 良末等 宣 布 大命 乎 (Sumera ga Omikotoramato Noritamau Omikoto wo)
天皇 我 大命 良末等 宣 布 大命 乎 (Sumera ga Omikotoramato Noritamau Omikoto wo)

sen.j: 衆聞食 倍止 宣。
sen.e: 衆聞食 倍止 宣。
衆聞食 倍止 宣。(Moromoro Kikoshimesaeto Noru.)
衆聞食 倍止 宣。(Moromoro Kikoshimesaeto Noru.)

sen.j: 此 乃 天平勝宝九歳三月廿日
sen.e: 此 乃 天平勝宝九歳三月廿日
sen.cmt: 「この天平勝宝九歳三月廿日に」
sen.e: 此 乃 天平勝宝九歳三月廿日 (Kono Tenpyo Shoho Kyusai Sangatsu Hatsuka)
此 乃 天平勝宝九歳三月廿日 (Kono Tenpyo Shoho Kyusai Sangatsu Hatsuka)

sen.j: 天 乃 賜 倍留 大 奈留
sen.e: 天 乃 賜 倍留 大 奈留
sen.cmt: 「天が与えてくさだった大きな瑞物を、」
sen.e: 天 乃 賜 倍留 大 奈留 (Ame no Tamaeru Oinaru)
天 乃 賜 倍留 大 奈留 (Ame no Tamaeru Oinaru)

sen.j: 瑞 乎 頂 尓 受賜 波理
sen.e: 瑞 乎 頂 尓 受賜 波理
瑞 乎 頂 尓 受賜 波理 (Shirushi wo Itadaki ni Uketamawari)
瑞 乎 頂 尓 受賜 波理 (Shirushi wo Itadaki ni Uketamawari)

sen.j: 天皇（すめら）が大命（おほみこと）らまと宣（のりたま）ふ大命を
sen.e: I am going to proclaim my imperial command as your Empress.
I am going to proclaim my imperial command as your Empress.
I am going to proclaim my imperial command as your Empress.

sen.j: 衆（もろもろ）聞食（きこしめさ）へと宣（のる）。
sen.e: Everybody, listen to me carefully.
Everybody, listen to me carefully.
Everybody, listen to me carefully.

sen.j: 此（こ）の天平勝宝九歳三月廿日
sen.e: Today, April 17, 757.
Today is August 23, 749.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直しました。
sen.e: Today is August 23, 749.

sen.j: 天（あめ）の賜（たま）へる大（おほい）なる
sen.e: Heaven gave me a great lucky omen.
Heaven gave me a great lucky omen.
Heaven gave me a great lucky omen.

sen.j: 瑞（しるし）を頂（いただき）に受賜（うけたま）はり
sen.e: I am happy to have it on my head.
I am happy to have it on my head.
I am happy to have it on my head.
